awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: A Modeling-Based Investigation in Support of Pioneer Array Relocation Design in the Southern Mid-Atlantic Bight
awd_abstract_narration:
Through a series of NSF sponsored Pioneer Array Innovations Labs, the new location for the NSF Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) Pioneer Coastal Array will be relocated to the Southern Mid-Atlantic Bight (S-MAB), in the region between Cape Hatteras, NC, and Norfolk Canyon, VA. In order to inform specific array design decisions, such as mooring siting, spacing, and instrument/sensor selection and configuration it is important to perform ocean numerical modeling analysis of the complex and dynamic ocean circulation to provide guidance to the OOI-CGSN Pioneer Array system design and build group that meets their published milestones/constraints for the design and build-out timeline. The results of this modelling effort would strengthen future model-based co-design of NSF-supported field programs, including the next Pioneer redeployment in another five (5) years. This project offers opportunities to develop strong partnerships with stakeholders in academia, government, and industry sectors, including marine fisheries and offshore renewable energy (wind and hydrokinetic).


The PI's proposes to perform a suite of numerical modeling investigations and analyses to deliver actionable guidance to the OOI-CGSN Pioneer Array system design and build group that meets their published milestones/constraints for the design and build-out timeline. Skillful ocean modeling and analysis will offer a virtual ocean framework – a “digital twin” ocean – that can be used to inform specific array design decisions, such as mooring siting, spacing, and instrument/sensor selection and configuration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation’s Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) aims to advance oceanographic research by providing crucial real-time data. A significant development in this initiative is the relocation of the Pioneer Coastal Array to the Southern Mid-Atlantic Bight (S-MAB), a region extending from Cape Hatteras, NC, to Norfolk Canyon, VA. This relocation promises to enrich our understanding of critical oceanographic phenomena and foster robust collaborations across various sectors.

Objectives and Scientific Questions

The relocation of the Pioneer Array is driven by the desire to explore several scientific questions crucial to understanding our marine environment. These include:

  • The impact of land-ocean interactions and variability on the export of S-MAB waters.
  • How cross-shelf transports influence regional biogeochemical cycles and marine ecosystems.

To address these questions, the array's positioning has been carefully planned to cover essential natural system interactions like land-estuary-shelf-ocean dynamics, and to capture key environmental variabilities at short scales.

Achievements

In collaboration with North Carolina State University and Rutgers University, we have initiated a comprehensive ocean modeling project to support the Pineer Array designs. This project leverages existing models from the NSF PEACH project to simulate and analyze the S-MAB’s dynamic ocean circulation. These efforts aim to provide actionable insights into the optimal design and placement of the Pioneer Array, enhancing its ability to monitor environmental changes effectively.

Specific Achievements:

  1. Characterization of Regional Circulation: Our team developed detailed statistical models of ocean conditions in the S-MAB, focusing on variables like sea surface height and salinity. This information is critical for the engineering design of moorings and sensor placement.

  2. 3-D Transport Pathways: We have identified key transport corridors within the S-MAB and analyzed their variability. This analysis helps determine the optimal array configuration to monitor significant oceanographic processes without blind spots.

  3. Array Design Assessment: Using digital twin ocean models, we evaluated different array configurations, such as T-shaped and W-shaped arrays. These assessments ensure that the array design is optimized for capturing essential data on ocean circulation and transport.

Community Engagement and Open Access

Throughout the project, we have maintained active engagement with the scientific community and stakeholders. This has included regular updates and feedback sessions through various OOI communication channels. Additionally, we are committed to providing open access to high-resolution, 3-D hydrodynamic model outputs and supporting data, allowing for broader community analysis and collaboration. Two peer-reviewed publications were produced to document research findings.

Conclusion

The relocation of the Pioneer Coastal Array to the S-MAB represents a strategic enhancement of our ocean observation capabilities. The array’s new position enables unprecedented research opportunities in critical areas such as ecosystem dynamics and climate change. By leveraging advanced modeling techniques and fostering community engagement, this project sets a new standard in oceanographic research, promising to deliver insights that are vital for environmental management and scientific advancement.
